coreCitation.title: United States Census Bureau TIGER/Line Census Tracts
coreCitation.briefGenealogy: A common process is to join statistical demographic data from the American Community Survey or decennial census with census shape data like tracts, counties or states.
coreCitation.fullNotes: Census data is obtained by using online websites such as the official Census Bureau tool, American Fact Finder, or websites from other reputable census data providers. The Leventhal Map & Education Center recommends using [NHGIS.org](http://nhgis.org/), which streamlines the process of accessing census data for GIS purposes, specifically. You can go to [NHGIS.org](http://nhgis.org/) to access the exact demographic characteristics and geographical units necessary for your research project. You can scroll down in this metadata record to find the 'tutorials' section, which will point to step-by-step instructions for working with census data using [NHGIS.org](http://nhgis.org/).
coreCitation.accessCondition: This data is in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use.

temporal.temporalNotes: Census data, while dating back to the 1790s, was collected in slightly different ways for every census year. This means that the way census geographies and demographic categories are available is subject to nuance, depending on which year you are looking for. NHGIS.org has this handy documentation that includes data availability tables for any given census year: https://nhgis.org/user-resources/data-availability

documentation.title: Geographic Areas Reference Manual: Census Tracts

tutorials.title: Working with NHGIS and Joins
tutorials.author: Creighton University Digital Humanities
tutorials.notes: Learn how to join census data with demographic data in QGIS

representation.healthCheckQualifier:
The Census Bureau's ACS Design & Methodology Report details the process by which survey questions were first developed and how stakeholders were initially included in that process.  
 
 The Census Bureau does not make documentation available on the topic of ongoing plans for inclusion of the voices of those represented by and most impacted by the survey.

publicResponsibility.healthCheckQualifier:
The Census Bureau's ACS Design and Methodology Report is healthy on issues related to technical methodology for geographic aggregation and anonymization. It also discusses how the Census Bureau understands the mandatory nature of the Census, and the reasons why the data is beneficial to society. 
 
 There is not healthy documentation available on any known privacy issues or methods taken to ensure all participants understand how their data will be used.

historicContext.healthCheckQualifier: The documentation does not reflect on the ways the data program is at risk for repeating past harms. It does not describe the ways in which U.S. census data collection has considered its relationship and contribution to systemic injustice.

methodology.healthCheckQualifier:
The Census Bureau's ACS Design and Methodology Report provides extremely healthy documentation about the technical methdologies used to produce the survey data. 
 
 The documentation could state more clearly how the data should and should not be used, with clearer remarks about known limitations.

potentialImpact.healthCheckQualifier:
There is healthy documentation about potential positive impact and future funding dependent on this data program. 
 
 There is not very much easily discoverable documentation about potential negative impact, especially if there are existing factors which should be flagged to avoid harm.

maintenance.maintenanceFrequency: These datasets are added to NHGIS within four - six weeks of the official census release.
